awd_titl_txt: CHS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Augmented Reality Agents with Pervasive Awareness, Appearance, and Abilities
awd_abstract_narration:
Voice-based assistants that respond to commands of people can be thought of as virtual companions that are always standing by to play music, tell us the weather, turn the lights off, etc. While their powers to respond and act on our behalf are increasing, unlike real companions they are largely unaware of our presence, take little initiative, look like appliances rather than interaction partners, and have limited abilities to both respond to queries and to sense and control real objects around us. This project will develop Augmented Reality Agents (ARAs) to embody these voice-based assistants, making them more are aware of our appearance, emotions, and behaviors, giving dynamic visual representations that make us aware of their state and behaviors; and leveraging the growth in "Internet of Things" (IoT) infrastructure and devices to increase the breadth and depth of their awareness. Together, these advances will lead to more effective and accepted voice-based assistants, both in the home and beyond. Such ARAs have a number of potential applications, including healthcare (by increasing the realism of clinical simulation and training, or providing support for caregiving through remote communication and virtual companionship) and education (by being more engaging tutors or representing historically important individuals). 
 
To develop embodied Augmented Reality Agents (ARAs) with pervasive contextual awareness, appearance, and abilities the researchers will undertake a program of research aimed at the nexus of concepts and technologies associated with Augmented Reality (AR), Intelligent Virtual Agents (IVA), and the Internet of Things (IoT). To maximize the expected knowledge outcomes the researchers have organized their plans into three categories. First, they will develop new understanding of and priorities for ARA awareness, appearance, and abilities in a manner that does not require, nor depend on, a specific technological realization of automated behaviors. Second, they will use off-the-shelf and custom components to realize pervasive ARA functionality, to facilitate formative experiments related to basic ARA behaviors, and develop domain-specific applications and experiments. Third, the researchers will use application-specific realizations to assess the potential usefulness related to companionship and two areas of healthcare training: pediatric patient simulators and wide-area team-based medical training. The healthcare-focused work will leverage relevant courses at UF and UCF, and UCF's NSF REU center on the Internet of Things to engage students beyond their core team, in meaningful research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The high-level research-related goals of this project included the development of novel systems and methods at the nexus of three technology thrusts: Intelligent Virtual Agents (IVAs), Internet of Things (IoT), and Augmented Reality (AR). A primary focus of the project was on Augmented Reality Agents (ARA). The effort includeded the development of ARA theories, expectations for human behavior in the presense of ARAs, models and prototypes of ARAs, and human subjects experiments to explore related hypotheses for human behavior. 

The high-level education-related goals of this project included the development of both graduate and undergraduate students, including both professional development in research, with experience in research, publications and other work products, and professional interaction. Specifically to support the development of undergraduate experiences, we applied for and were awarded an REU supplement --- additional funds solely to support Research Experiences for Undergraduates. The REU students worked both on the core research, and in some instances, with permission of the NSF Program Officers, on other research where there was a need and a good match with the student, thus maximizing the value of the REU activitity.

Over the entire period of this award, including no-cost extensions, nine faculty / reseaerchers were involved in the mentoring and professional development of 17 students: seven graduate students and 10 undergrads students. The research and mentoring resulted in at least 76 publications, two PhD dissertations, and one patent. Of the 76 publications, we mentored undergradaute students in the intellectual and practical leadership of authorship, resulting in six publications where undergraduates were the lead auithors.  

 


Last Modified: 08/30/2024
Modified by: Gregory F Welch

Images (1 of )
  • Some notional examples of the uses of embodied Augmented Reality Agents, including uses in the home, e.g., cooking, helping children with homework, and visiting with relatives; and at work, e.g., for the training of nurses, doctors, and others in a hospital.
    Prof. Greg Welch
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Gregory F Welch
    Some notional examples of the uses of embodied Augmented Reality Agents
  • An example of an embodied Augmented Reality Agent ��a 3D visual representation of an audio-only agent associated with a consumer �smart speaker.�
    Prof. Greg Welch
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Gregory F Welch
    Example Augmented Reality Agent
  • In one human-subjects experiment we investigated the degree of trust in an agent when study participants could see her leave to turn off a light, as opposed to only hearing her say that she did so (with no image of her doing so). Participants trusted more when they saw her leave and return.
    Prof. Greg Welch
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Gregory F Welch
    Example Augmented Reality Agent Turning Off Lights
